title: Jimmy Hartwig
text:
William "Jimmy" Hartwig (born 5 October 1954) is a German former professional <a href="association%20football">footballer</a> who played as a <a href="defensive%20midfielder">defensive midfielder</a>. He played for <a href="Kickers%20Offenbach">Kickers Offenbach</a>, <a href="TSV%201860%20Munich">TSV 1860 Munich</a>, <a href="Hamburger%20SV">Hamburger SV</a>, <a href="1.%20FC%20K%C3%B6ln">1. FC Köln</a> and <a href="FC%20Homburg">FC Homburg</a> of the <a href="Bundesliga">Bundesliga</a> and for <a href="FC%20Red%20Bull%20Salzburg">Austria Salzburg</a> of Austria. The son of an African-American soldier and a German mother, Hartwig was one of the first <a href="black%20people">black</a> players in German and Austrian football.
Hartwig won the European Cup in 1983 with Hamburger SV, and was three times German league champion in 1979, 1982 und 1983 and three times league runner-up with Hamburger SV. He also earned two caps for the <a href="West%20Germany%20national%20football%20team">West Germany national team</a>, making him only the second non-white player (after <a href="Erwin%20Kostedde">Erwin Kostedde</a>) to achieve this feat.
After his playing career, Hartwig worked as a coach at <a href="FC%20Augsburg">FC Augsburg</a> in 1989 and <a href="FC%20Sachsen%20Leipzig">FC Sachsen Leipzig</a> in 1990. He entered the TV business, where he has been working ever since, whilst also appearing in the theatre as an actor.
Personal life.
In his 1994 autobiography, Hartwig described his tough childhood in the city of <a href="Offenbach%20am%20Main">Offenbach am Main</a> where he was born. He recounted a childhood full of poverty and anti-black racism, with only his German mother as support; his biological African father from Senegal never took care of him.
Hartwig is married for the fourth time and has three children.
In 2021, he featured in "", a documentation detailing the experiences of <a href="Black%20people">Black</a> players in German professional football.
Singing.
In 1980, the single "Mama Calypso" was released, with "Sometimes" on the reverse side, on the <a href="RCA%20Records">RCA label</a>.
